descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
French 101-B is the second quarter of a three-quarter sequence of Elementary French. The aim of the course is to build skills in speaking, understanding, writing and reading French through class activities, practice, and study. A variety of class activities are designed to help students acquire knowledge of the basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. It uses a multimedia approach that incorporates texts, songs, videos, and the internet and helps students acquire linguistic as well as cultural competence. Classes include a variety of activities designed to help students acquire knowledge of basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. By the end of the three-quarter sequence, students will be able to create with the language to talk about familiar topics related to daily life and to express personal meaning.

Schedule note: this is a hybrid course, which meets once every week for two hours (6:15-8:15 pm) on campus, and requires a weekly one-hour online session that students can complete on their own time. An online workbook manual will be used for homework.

Carries humanities credit (two-course limit for language courses).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: FRENCH 101-A or equivalent. This course is for students with less than two years of high school French or with no previous study of French.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: In this course, we will cover elementary grammatical structures and vocabulary in order for you to become proficient at an introductory level. In order to get the most out of this course, you should speak only French (that includes asking questions in class)! One of the best ways to learn a language is through constant practice, by assimilating concepts and vocabulary, and by having the courage to create with language and to make mistakes!

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Classes will be conducted exclusively in French except when explanation of administrative information may necessitate the use of English. Students are expected to study and practice regularly throughout the week (between classes), prepare for the next week's lesson, to participate actively in class activities, to speak only French in class, and to work independently with the En Avant! listening program and the En Avant! Internet activities. The instructor will not teach grammar explicitly, instead we will practice grammar in communicative class activities.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Anderson, Golato and Blatty, En Avant!, second edition. Anderson, Golato and Blatty, En Avant! WorkBook and Laboratory Manual (WBLM) online version, second ed. The textbook with online access code are available in a bundle at the Norris Bookstore. The bundle includes access to online material. Course packet (distributed in first class). **All quarters: French 101-a, 101-b, and 101-c will use the above texts.**

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Classes are conducted in French except when explanations of grammar or administrative matters require the use of English. Students are expected to prepare outside of class, to participate actively in class activities, and to work independently with the En Avant! online program and Workbook / Laboratory Manual throughout the week. This is a hybrid course, which meets once every week for two hours (6:15-8:15 pm) on campus, and requires a weekly one-hour online session that students can complete on their own time. An online workbook manual will be used for homework .
